authors: Andebo Waza;Alexandre Deguine;Soulemane Ngagine;Pascal Flament;Patrick Augustin;Fabrice Cazier;Hervé Delbarre;Dorothée Dewaele;Elsa Dieudonne;Marc Fourmentin;Karine Deboudt
title: Critical factors influencing PM<sub>10</sub> and PM<sub>2.5</sub> pollution episodes and their associated particle chemical composition and mixing state in a coastal multisources area
abstract:
•PM2.5pollution plumes are frequently regional in extent, while PM10plumes are more local. •A highly heterogeneous composition of particles is observed on pollution days. •During pollution days, particle composition and mixing state change quickly due to local meteorological effects. •Sea breezes and recirculation periods strongly impact pollutant dispersion and ageing in coastal area. 
 In Europe, a large proportion of the population lives in industrial and urban coastal areas, due to their role as hubs of population migration and economic activity. Despite regulatory efforts, these areas frequently experience PM10 and PM2.5 pollution episodes due to the high density of emission sources combined with complex atmospheric dynamics. In this context, we investigate pollution days (PDs) over a 4-year period (2018–2021) on the Great Dunkirk Area, a coastal region significantly affected by diverse pollution sources. We show that PM2.5 pollution plumes predominantly exhibit regional extension, while PM10 plumes are more often local, with clear seasonal patterns. Using SEM-EDX analysis of over 23,000 individual particles collected during the 2021 MIXTAPE campaign, we reveal a highly heterogeneous aerosol composition, dominated by sea salt and carbonaceous particles, with fine particles enriched in sulfur secondary species and coarse particles in calcium. The mixing state index (χ) ranges from 0.5 to 0.9, indicating a continuum from external to internal mixtures, strongly influenced by atmospheric ageing, recirculation, and turbulent mixing. Our results highlight that neither local wind direction nor plume extension alone can explain the observed chemical variability. Instead, the evolution of particle composition and mixing state depends on fine-scale meteorological dynamics including sea breezes and recirculation periods affecting pollutant dispersion and ageing. This work underlines the need to incorporate high-resolution particle chemistry and urban-scale atmospheric dynamics in air quality assessments and demonstrates the added value of single-particle analysis in complex, multisource coastal environments.

explanation: 该研究论文主要关注室内环境中半挥发性有机化合物（SVOCs），特别是邻苯二甲酸酯（phthalates）在气相和颗粒相之间的分配行为，以及空气交换率（AER）对这种分配的影响。研究通过实验测量了邻苯二甲酸二丁酯（DnBP）和邻苯二甲酸二乙酯（DEP）在无机氯化钠（NaCl）颗粒上的分配系数（Kp），并探讨了AER对Kp的影响。研究结果表明，DnBP的Kp值高于DEP，且Kp值与混合时间呈正相关。较高的AER会导致较低的颗粒相SVOCs浓度。因此，该研究与大气环境遥感技术（如空气质量监测、卫星观测和大气成分分析）关联不大，主要集中在室内空气质量和通风策略对SVOCs行为的影响。

authors: Azad Bahrami;Fariborz Haghighat;Jiping Zhu;Jianjun Niu
title: Influence of residence time on the particle-gas partitioning of phthalates onto airborne inorganic particle
abstract:
•The gaseous DnBP and DEP were generated in a quasi-stable system. •DnBP possessed higher Kpthan DEP due to its lower vapor pressure. •Higher AER led to lower SVOCs particle-phase concentration. 
 In indoor environments, the presence of particulate matter promotes SVOCs volatilization, increasing their overall concentration in the air. This effect arises from the partition of SVOCs between the gas and particulate phases. The particle-gas partition ratio (Kp) is a critical parameter influencing the fate, transport, and human exposure to indoor SVOCs. Air exchange rate (AER) is a pivotal factor in closed spaces as it regulates the residence time of airborne SVOCs in an indoor environment. It has been reported that AER (or residence time) can affect particle-gas partitioning behavior for organic particles when equilibrium between gas and particle phases is not reached; however, its effect on inorganic particles has not been thoroughly investigated. This study develops an experimental procedure to measure Kp of Di-n-butyl phthalate (DnBP) and Diethyl phthalate (DEP) with inorganic sodium chloride (NaCl) particles. Results shows that DnBP had higher Kp values than DEP. Positive correlation of Kp values and mixing time was observed. These findings are consistent with model predictions. Further experiments were carried out to study the impact of AER on Kp, and the results shown that higher air exchange rates (lower residence time) result in lower particle-phase concentrations of SVOCs due to increased dilution and reduced interaction time with particles. These findings have important implications for indoor air quality assessments, highlighting the influence of ventilation strategies on SVOCs behavior in indoor environments.

authors: Mao Xu;Phuvasa Chanonmuang;Syuichi Itahashi;Hiroyuki Sase;Kazuhide Matsuda
title: Characteristics of PM<sub>2.5</sub> concentrations in a tropical dry deciduous forest of Thailand: Forest fires and urban air pollution seriously affect air quality in forest ecosystems
abstract:
•We measured PM2.5above a dry deciduous forest in a remote area of Thailand. •Forest fire altered typical PM2.5composition by generating biomass burning aerosols. •Forest served as a receptor of long-range transported urban/industrial air pollution. •Forest fire considerably raised PM2.5concentration and served as a large source. 
 Particulate matter with an aerodynamic diameter equal to or less than 2.5 μm (PM2.5) remains a serious issue in Asia. To address the lack of observational data and investigate the status of PM2.5 in the forests, we collected PM2.5 above a tropical dry deciduous forest in a remote area of northeastern Thailand during the dry season. Notably, a large-scale surface fire occurred at the forest site during the mid-dry season. We also analyzed the PM2.5 data collected by the Pollution Control Department of Thailand and the satellite-based aerosol optical depth (AOD) over Southeast Asia. Three episodes of elevated PM2.5 concentration were observed at the site. Based on the ground-based measurements and AOD, two episodes were attributable to the long-range transport from urban areas in Vietnam and Thailand. The proportion of SO42− increased in the two episodes, indicating SO42− was a key indicator for identifying the sources of air pollution. While NH4+, NO3−, and SO42− dominated approximately 83 % of the total concentration of water-soluble inorganic ions (WSII) during the non-fire periods, the forest fire substantially altered the chemical composition, with K+ and Cl− accounting for approximately 42 %. The maximum concentration of total WSII in PM2.5 during the forest fire period reached 88.0 μg m−3, which was approximately three times higher than that during the non-fire periods (26.4 μg m−3). The forest site served not only as a receptor of urban air pollution but also as a large source of PM2.5. Enhancing regional cooperation and forest management is necessary in this region.

explanation: 该研究论文关注的是京津冀地区空气污染和二氧化碳排放的协同效应及其驱动因素。它利用高分辨率排放清单和WRF-CAMx模型来量化不同部门对二氧化碳排放以及PM2.5和O3浓度的贡献。研究通过污染控制效率、弹性系数和耦合协调度等指标，系统评估了协同效应，并结合地理探测器分析和计量经济学模型揭示了这些协同效应的驱动机制。虽然没有直接提及遥感技术，但其对空气污染物（如PM2.5和臭氧）的监测和排放清单的依赖，暗示了遥感数据在支持排放清单编制和验证中的潜在应用，因此与大气环境遥感技术具有一定的相关性。

abstract:
•Contributions of different sources and their synergies are quantified. •Driving factors and driving effects of synergies are explored. •Synergies and drivers exhibit spatiotemporal and sectoral heterogeneity. •Technological innovation and population have significant impacts on synergies. •Total energy consumption and energy intensity are key drivers of synergies. 
 Investigating the synergistic effects of air pollution and carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions and their influencing factors is crucial for developing more scientific environmental governance and climate change mitigation strategies. This study investigated spatiotemporal patterns of air pollutants and CO2 emissions in the Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei (BTH) region during two distinct phases (2018–2020 and 2020–2022). Through integration of high-resolution emission inventories with WRF-CAMx modeling, sectoral contributions to CO2 emissions and to PM2.5 and O3 concentrations were quantified. A systematic assessment of synergistic effects employed three metrics: pollution control efficiency, elasticity coefficients, and coupling coordination degree. Finally, geographic detector analysis combined with econometric modeling revealed driving mechanisms underlying these synergistic effects, incorporating spatial correlations and causal inference. The results indicated a continuous decline in air pollutants and CO2 emissions across most cities in the BTH region from 2018 to 2022, with notable heterogeneity in the synergistic effects contributed by different sectors. Fine particulate matter (PM2.5) and CO2 exhibited stronger synergistic effects compared to ozone (O3) and CO2. These effects were positively influenced by population size and negatively impacted by energy consumption intensity. Total standard energy consumption and energy consumption intensity had relatively greater influences. Furthermore, there were interaction effects between different influencing factors, including two-factor enhancement and nonlinear enhancement. This study provided valuable scientific insights for enhancing the synergistic management of environmental pollution alleviation and carbon emission control in future phases, and offered strategic guidance for more effective integration of air quality improvement and climate change mitigation efforts.

authors: Abhishek Thakur;Chhavi P. Pandey;Aman Shrivas;Atul K. Srivastava;Pyar S. Negi
title: Black carbon aerosol characteristics over Gangotri glacier valley in North-Western Himalaya: Long-range transport and implications to radiative forcing
abstract:
•In-situ observations recorded mean eBC concentration of 0.28 ± 0.21 μg/m3at the high-altitude Himalayan site, Bhojbasa (∼3800 m amsl). •eBC induced radiative forcing (+6.71 ± 1.80 W/m² ) caused substantial warming in the atmosphere with a heating rate of 0.19 ± 0.05 K/day in this sensitive Himalayan region. •Long-range transport from IGP, impact of westerlies, and monsoonal transport, can be seen. •Fossil fuel emissions dominate eBC sources (78 %), while meteorological parameters strongly influence the eBC variations. 
 The Himalayan glacier valleys are encountering escalating environmental challenges. One of the contributing factors is thought to be the rising amounts of light-absorbing carbonaceous aerosols, particularly brown carbon (BrC) and black carbon (BC), that are reaching glacier valleys. The present study examines the optical and radiative characteristics of BC at Bhojbasa, near Gaumukh (∼3800amsl). Real-time in-situ BC data, optical characteristics, radiative forcing, heating rate, several meteorological parameters, and BC transport pathways to this high-altitude site are investigated. The daily mean concentration of equivalent black carbon (eBC) was 0.28 ± 0.21 μg/m3 over the research period, and the eBC from fossil fuel (BCFF) is dominant with 78 % with a daily mean of 0.22 ± 0.19 μg/m3, and eBC from biomass burning (BCBB) is 22 % with a daily mean of 0.06 ± 0.08 μg/m3. Meteorological data, Cloud-Aerosol Lidar and Infrared Pathfinder Satellite Observation (CALIPSO) imaging, and backward air-mass trajectory analysis demonstrate the presence of BC particles and their plausible transit pathways from multiple source locations to the pristine Gangotri Glacier Valley. The estimated daily mean BC radiative forcing values are +6.71 ± 1.80 W/m2 in the atmosphere, +1.87 ± 1.16 W/m2 at the top of the atmosphere, and −4.84 ± 1.01 W/m2 at the surface with a corresponding atmospheric heating rate of 0.19 ± 0.05 K/day. These findings highlight the critical role of ground-based measurements in monitoring the fluctuations of BC over such varied Himalayan terrain, as they offer important information on the localized trends and effects. Long-term measurements of glacier valleys are essential for a comprehensive evaluation of the impact of BC particles on Himalayan ecology and climate.

authors: Linghong Chen;Hongze Cai;Changjian Yin;Kaicun Wang
title: Stronger rise in humid heatwaves over China shown by homogenized data from 1961 to 2022
abstract:
•A homogenized, high-resolution (0.1° × 0.1°) wet-bulb temperature dataset is used to quantified humid heatwaves. •Humid heatwave severity is characterized using cumulative intensity, demonstrating higher positive trend (1.71 °C/decade) than unhomogenized heatwave (1.29 °C/decade). •After homogenization, the humid heatwave severity increased by 26.6 % during 2010–2022. 
 A growing body of evidence has established the intensification of global humid heatwaves. With a large population and diverse ecosystem, humid heatwave in China has garnered scientific attention. Divergent conclusions across previous research of humid heatwave severity stem from the variations in wet-bulb temperature data source and heatwave characteristics. Robust wet-bulb temperature with high spatiotemporal resolution and cumulative heatwave characteristics, would enable more consistent assessments of humid heatwaves. Here, we generate regular gridded data of wet-bulb temperature, based on homogenized air temperature and relative humidity from station observational records across China. Meanwhile, we propose a cumulative heatwave intensity characteristic to quantify humid heatwaves severity, with inter-annual and cross-regional comparisons. The homogenized cumulative intensity characteristic reveals a significant increasing trend from 1961 to 2022. The national time-averaged value of the cumulative intensity during 1990–2022 (8.11 °C) exceeds twice the value of 1961–1990 (2.94 °C). The analysis identifies the Tibetan Plateau and Northwestern China as hotspots for humid heatwaves. These regions exhibit both higher multi-year mean severity and stronger intensification trends. The homogenization procedure reveals more extensive regions across China exhibiting both stronger and statistically significant intensification trends in heatwave severity. Additionally, the homogenized national mean trend of cumulative intensity of humid heatwave (1.71 °C/decade) surpass that derived from unhomogenized data (1.29 °C/decade). The cumulative intensity of humid heatwaves exhibits considerable discrepancy after homogenization, especially in post-1990. The relative discrepancy reaches 26.6 % during 2010–2022, while partial homogenization of temperature contributes − 9.3 %, partial homogenization of relative humidity contributes 48.0 %. This study investigates the rapid intensification of humid heatwaves across China under global warming, while highlighting how observational inhomogeneity systematically underestimate associated risks.

explanation: 该研究论文主要关注华北雨季期间的强降水特征以及NCEP S2S模型的预测能力。论文将华北地区的强降水分为两类，并分析了不同类型强降水形成的原因，以及NCEP S2S模型对不同类型强降水的预测技巧。研究发现，模型对第一类强降水（集中在京津冀地区）的预测技巧较低，主要是因为模型未能准确预测西太平洋副热带高压（WPSH）的北抬。而对于第二类强降水（发生在华北南部），模型具有较高的预测技巧，这归因于其能够预测南亚高压（SAH）的东伸。该研究与大气环境遥感技术（如空气质量监测、卫星观测和大气成分分析）没有直接关联，主要侧重于气象学和气候预测。

authors: Ting Zheng;Zhihai Zheng;Peiyi Fan;Xintong Hou;Guolin Feng
title: The characteristics of heavy rainfall during the rainy season over North China and prediction skill of NCEP S2S
abstract:
•The heavy rainfall in North China are divided into two types: one type is concentrated in the Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei region, while the other occurs in southern North China. •The first type of heavy rainfall is mainly due to the PJ pattern strengthening the WPSH. The second type is due to the eastward extension of the SAH. •The low forecast skill of the NCEP S2S for the first type is primarily because the model fails to predict the WPSH. The model exhibits higher forecasting skill for the second type and the SAH. 
 The North China region is one of the most core areas in China. Understanding the characteristics of heavy precipitation during the North China rainy season is of great significance for predicting and preventing flood disasters in this region. Precipitation in North China in 2024 ranked fourth in the past 45 years. Therefore, we conducted a study of the precipitation in North China in 2024 and found that the precipitation anomaly center was located in the eastern part of North China. Based on this, we conducted an analysis of the distribution characteristics of heavy rainfall of North China and found that it can be divided into two types: one type of heavy rainfall is concentrated in the Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei, while the other occurs in southern North China. Heavy rainfall concentrated in the Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei region is mainly due to the descending branch of the Pacific-Japan (PJ) pattern coinciding with the center of the Western Pacific Subtropical High (WPSH), thereby strengthening the northward-jumping WPSH. The low forecast skill of the National Centers for Environmental Prediction (NCEP) Sub-seasonal to Seasonal (S2S) model for the first type of heavy rainfall is primarily because the model fails to predict the northward shift of the WPSH, leading to a southern bias in the forecasted anomaly center. Heavy rainfall occurring in the southern part of North China is due to the eastward extension of the eastern boundary of the South Asian High (SAH), which brings a large amount of moisture and strengthens the WPSH. The NCEP S2S model exhibits modestly higher forecasting skill for the second type of heavy rainfall compared to the first, attributed to its ability to predict the eastward extension of the SAH. The 2024 precipitation anomaly in North China aligns more closely with a hybrid of the first and second rainfall types. This pattern correlates with an unusually intense and northward-displaced WPSH, coupled with an exceptionally eastward-extended eastern boundary of the SAH. Consequently, the model successfully predicted the precipitation anomaly in southeastern North China but exhibited limited skill in forecasting anomalies across the Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei region.

title: Future trend of lightning activity over the Tibetan Plateau under global warming
abstract:
•k-fold cross validation ensures the stability and robustness of the proxies •thermodynamic factors dominate the change of lightning activity at interannual scale over the Tibetan Plateau •lightning activity over the Tibetan Plateau increases significantly by the end of this century based on proxies 
 Under global warming, the change of lightning activity is a controversial issue. This study investigates historical trends in lightning over the Tibetan Plateau (TP) based on 18-years lightning data detected by optical transient detector (OTD) and lightning imaging sensor (LIS). Local and remote meteorological factors from reanalysis datasets are used to analyze the primary parameters controlling the change of lightning activity. To explore the proxy of lightning flash density over the TP, we employed multiple linear regression through k-fold cross validation. Furthermore, future projections of lightning activity are examined based on outputs of climate models from Coupled Model Intercomparison Project 6 (CMIP6). Historical analysis reveals that flash density over the eastern TP has shown consistently positive trends with a significant increase at a rate of 0.064 fl km−2y−2 over the entire observation period. Our ensemble model mean indicates that sea surface temperature of northwest of Australia and local surface temperature are closely related to the interannual variations in lightning activity over the eastern TP, accounting for 67 % of the variation in flash density. By applying the developed regional proxy to climate models, our projections suggest that lightning activity will increase by 32 % under SSP1–2.6 scenario and by 60 % under SSP2–4.5 scenario by the end of this century.
